elements.content: Metal–organic framework (MOF) nanoparticles with high porosity and greater tunability have emerged as new drug delivery vehicles. However, premature drug release still remains a challenge in the MOF delivery system. Here, we report an enzyme-responsive, polymer-coated MOF gatekeeper system using hyaluronic acid (HA) and PCN-224 nanoMOF. The external surface of nanoMOF can be stably covered by HA through multivalent coordination bonding between the Zr cluster and carboxylic acid of HA, which acts as a gatekeeper. HA allows selective accumulation of drug carriers in CD44 overexpressed cancer cells and enzyme-responsive drug release in the cancer cell environment. In particular, inherent characteristics of PCN-224, which is used as a drug carrier, facilitates the transfer of the drug to cancer cells more stably and allows photodynamic therapy. This HA-PCN system enables a dual chemo and photodynamic therapy to enhance the cancer therapy effect.

elements.content: Cancer is a public health threat worldwide, responsible for 609 940 deaths in the United States alone in 2018. Although chemotherapy is a popular cancer treatment therapy, direct administration of anticancer drugs often causes severe side effects. Development of drug delivery vehicles, which regulate drug release while minimizing side effects and maintaining therapeutic efficacy, is highly desirable. Drug delivery systems have been developed for the past few decades including inorganic mesoporous silica, quantum dots, metal nanoparticles, polymer nanoparticles, and organic dendrimers. However, these systems are still far from ideal drug delivery systems and difficult to satisfy the following important requirements simultaneously, including large drug loading capacity, colloidal stability, low toxicity, and biodegradability.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cancer is a public health threat worldwide, responsible for 609940 deaths in the United States alone in 2018. Although chemotherapy is a popular cancer treatment therapy, direct administration of anticancer drugs often causes severe side effects. Development of drug delivery vehicles, which regulate drug release while minimizing side effects and maintaining therapeutic efficacy, is highly desirable. Drug delivery systems have been developed for the past few decades including inorganic mesoporous silica, quantum dots, metal nanoparticles, polymer nanoparticles, and organic dendrimers. However, these systems are still far from ideal drug delivery systems and difficult to satisfy the following important requirements simultaneously, including large drug loading capacity, colloidal stability, low toxicity, and biodegradability.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous materials, are now emerging as new drug delivery vehicles due to their high porosity and greater tunability compared to those of conventional porous materials, providing multifunctionalities based on size, composition, topology, and chemical properties. However, controlled drug release has not been investigated extensively in these MOF-based systems. Most of the reported nanoMOFs has lack of colloidal stability in an aqueous environment and premature drug release behavior even without any stimuli as the surface of nanoMOFs is not fully covered. Drug encapsulated MOF have been studied to prevent unexpected drug release. The drug encapsulated during the MOF synthesis process was released through MOF degradation. However, the water stability and the simple loading for use of various drugs remains a challenge. To stably deliver drug molecules into cancer cells without undesired drug leakage before reaching target site and increase therapeutic effect by releasing the drug molecules inside the cancer cells, it is necessary to regulate drug release precisely by introducing the stable stimuli-sensitive system into the surface of nanoMOFs.
elements.clean_text: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a new class of porous materials, are now emerging as new drug delivery vehicles due to their high porosity and greater tunability compared to those of conventional porous materials, providing multifunctionalities based on size, composition, topology, and chemical properties. However, controlled drug release has not been investigated extensively in these MOF-based systems. Most of the reported nanoMOFs has lack of colloidal stability in an aqueous environment and premature drug release behavior even without any stimuli as the surface of nanoMOFs is not fully covered. Drug encapsulated MOF have been studied to prevent unexpected drug release. The drug encapsulated during the MOF synthesis process was released through MOF degradation. However, the water stability and the simple loading for use of various drugs remains a challenge. To stably deliver drug molecules into cancer cells without undesired drug leakage before reaching target site and increase therapeutic effect by releasing the drug molecules inside the cancer cells, it is necessary to regulate drug release precisely by introducing the stable stimuli-sensitive system into the surface of nanoMOFs.

elements.content: To achieve this goal, we design an enzyme-responsive polymer gatekeeper on nanoscale MOF (nanoMOF). First, we choose a nanoscale, Zr-based porphyrinic MOF, PCN-224, for a main component for the drug delivery system. This MOF is robust, yet biodegradable, with large surface area and stable over a wide range of pH. Furthermore, it can generate 1O2, an essential feature for photodynamic cancer therapy. Park et al. demonstrated the cellular uptake ability of PCN-224 as a photodynamic therapy (PDT) agent depending on the size of PCN-224. In this experiment, 90 nm PCN-224 shows the higher cellular uptake ability compare to that of 30, 60, 140, and 190 nm. After uptake, PCN-224 effectively induces cancer cell death up to 80% under 640 nm light irradiation. After loading drug molecules inside MOF, the nanoscale MOFs are covered with a gatekeeper, blocking the pore entrance to preserve drug molecules inside the pore to prevent premature release. Hyaluronic acid (HA), a natural polysaccharide with good biocompatibility, is chosen as a polymer gatekeeper. NanoMOFs covered with HA gatekeeper have several significant advantages: (i) the multiple coordination bonds between HA and the MOF make stable surface modification and keep the drug molecules inside the pore, (ii) hydrophilic HA on the MOFs provides a good colloidal stability in the water, (iii) HA acts as a cancer-targeting ligand for selective drug delivery because it can interact with CD44 that is overexpressed in many cancer cells, and (iv) HA is degraded by HAdase in cancer cells so that the drug molecules can be only released inside the cancer cell. For this reason, HA modification to the MOF has been studied to increase the cancer therapy effect. However, additional experimentation was required to modify HA to the MOF surface. We hypothesized that simply modified HA through a coordination bond directly on the MOF system would be a highly efficient drug delivery system for multimodal anticancer therapy. Herein, we report that the HA-nanoMOF system loaded with anticancer drug doxorubicin (Dox) is indeed highly efficient for cancer therapy. This approach is one step closer to precision medicine, providing multifunctional capabilities, including cancer-targeting, on-site drug release, and PDT (). This combined therapy, chemotherapy and PDT, demonstrated here is highly efficient for targeting multidrug-resistant cancer cells.

elements.content: All chemicals and reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, TCI, and Alfa Aesar, Korea unless otherwise specified and used without further purification. Sodium hyaluronate was purchased from Acros Organic (Belgium). Doxorubicin hydrochloride was obtained from Ontario Chemicals Inc., Canada. Deionized (DI) water was produced by the Millipore Milli-Q system (18.2 MΩ cm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

General Information

All chemicals and reagents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, TCI, and Alfa Aesar, Korea unless otherwise specified and used without further purification. Sodium hyaluronate was purchased from Acros Organic (Belgium). Doxorubicin hydrochloride was obtained from Ontario Chemicals Inc., Canada. Deionized (DI) water was produced by the Millipore Milli-Q system (18.2 MΩ cm).

elements.content: PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized in a solvothermal condition as reported. meso-tetra­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphine (TCPP) (100 mg, 0.13 mmol), ZrOCl2·8H2O (300 mg, 0.93 mmol), benzoic acid (2.8 g, 23 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (100 mL) were combined in a 250 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was heated to 90 °C for 5 h with 300 rpm stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The product was collected by centrifugation with 15 000 rpm for 30 min and washed by fresh DMF and acetone. The synthesized PCN-224 sample was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PCN-224 (100 nm)

PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized in a solvothermal condition as reported. meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl)porphine (TCPP) (100 mg, 0.13 mmol), ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (300 mg, 0.93 mmol), benzoic acid (2.8 g, 23 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (100 mL) were combined in a 250 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was heated to 90 °C for 5 h with 300 rpm stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The product was collected by centrifugation with 15000 rpm for 30 min and washed by fresh DMF and acetone. The synthesized PCN-224 sample was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

elements.content: Before gas adsorption measurement, 100 nm PCN-224 samples were thoroughly washed thrice with DMF and twice with acetone. After decanting acetone, samples were dried under vacuum for 3 h. Also, the dried powder was activated at 85 °C for 30 min and at 120 °C for 5 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for PCN-224 is 2296(8) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).
elements.clean_text:
Charaterization of Porous Coordination Network (PCN)

Before gas adsorption measurement, 100 nm PCN-224 samples were thoroughly washed thrice with DMF and twice with acetone. After decanting acetone, samples were dried under vacuum for 3 h. Also, the dried powder was activated at 85 °C for 30 min and at 120 °C for 5 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area for PCN-224 is 2296(8) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).

elements.content: PCN-224 (about 4 mg) dispersed in 8 mg of Dox was dissolved in 1 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and the mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. Then, the Dox-loaded PCN-224 was collected by centrifugation and dried under high vacuum. Then, dried samples were redispersed in DI water (pH 7). The supernatant solution containing unloaded Dox was analyzed under UV–visible spectra using the molar absorption coefficient. The drug loading capacity (%) is calculated as follows: mass of the drug in PCN-224/mass of PCN-224 × 100.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Dox-PCN

PCN-224 (about 4 mg) dispersed in 8 mg of Dox was dissolved in 1 mL of dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) and the mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. Then, the Dox-loaded PCN-224 was collected by centrifugation and dried under high vacuum. Then, dried samples were redispersed in DI water (pH 7). The supernatant solution containing unloaded Dox was analyzed under UV-visible spectra using the molar absorption coefficient. The drug loading capacity (%) is calculated as follows: mass of the drug in PCN-224/mass of PCN-224 × 100.

elements.content: The dried Dox-PCN sample was activated at 60 °C for 30 min and at 80 °C for 12 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The BET surface area for Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).
elements.clean_text:
Characterization of Dox-PCN

The dried Dox-PCN sample was activated at 60 °C for 30 min and at 80 °C for 12 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The BET surface area for Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).

elements.content: About 1 mg of Dox-loaded PCN were dispersed in 20 mL of DI water (pH 7) containing 2 mg of hyaluronic acid (HA), and the mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. Then, HA-coated Dox-PCN was collected by centrifugation and redispersed in DI water (pH 7). HA-Dox-PCN was washed three times by repeated centrifugation and redispersion. The supernatant solution containing unmodified HA was analyzed by the carbazole assay.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of HA-Dox-PCN

About 1 mg of Dox-loaded PCN were dispersed in 20 mL of DI water (pH 7) containing 2 mg of hyaluronic acid (HA), and the mixture was stirred for 24 h at room temperature. Then, HA-coated Dox-PCN was collected by centrifugation and redispersed in DI water (pH 7). HA-Dox-PCN was washed three times by repeated centrifugation and redispersion. The supernatant solution containing unmodified HA was analyzed by the carbazole assay.

elements.content:
TGA measurements of Dox-PCN and HA-Dox-PCN were carried out on a SDT Q600 model of TA Instruments at a heating rate of 5 °C/min.

Synthesis of Amine-Modified Fluorescein Isothiocyanate (FITC)

The amine functional group was modified to fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) to prepare FITC-HA. FITC (5 mg, 12 μmol) and ethylenediamine (1 μL, 18 μmol) were dissolved in 2 mL of DMSO. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solvents and ethylenediamine were removed by a freeze drier.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetry Analysis (TGA)

TGA measurements of Dox-PCN and HA-Dox-PCN were carried out on a SDT Q600 model of TA Instruments at a heating rate of 5 °C/min.

Synthesis of Amine-Modified Fluorescein Isothiocyanate (FITC)

The amine functional group was modified to fluorescein isothiocyanate (FITC) to prepare FITC-HA. FITC (5 mg, 12 μmol) and ethylenediamine (1 μL, 18 μmol) were dissolved in 2 mL of DMSO. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 12 h. The solvents and ethylenediamine were removed by a freeze drier.

elements.content: Hyaluronic acid (20 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of DI water (pH 7). Then, 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)­carbodiimide (15 mg, 97 μmol) and NHS (11 mg, 96 μmol) were added in HA solution. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Then, amine-modified FITC (2.2 mg, 5 μmol) was added in the mixture solution. After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the mixture was purified by dialysis using a 2.5 K dialysis bag for 1 week. After dialysis, the solution was removed by the freeze drier.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of FITC-HA

Hyaluronic acid (20 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of DI water (pH 7). Then, 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)carbodiimide (15 mg, 97 μmol) and NHS (11 mg, 96 μmol) were added in HA solution. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Then, amine-modified FITC (2.2 mg, 5 μmol) was added in the mixture solution. After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the mixture was purified by dialysis using a 2.5 K dialysis bag for 1 week. After dialysis, the solution was removed by the freeze drier.

elements.content: Release kinetics of HA-Dox-PCN was analyzed by a Shimadzu RFPC 5430 spectrophotometer. Nanoparticles were dispersed in phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4). After dispersion, the Dox fluorescence intensity was measured (excitation wavelength, 480 nm). To determine the induced drug release profile, HAdase (400 U/mL) was added to the nanoparticle solution at 4 h and the release profile was analyzed using fluorescence.
elements.clean_text:
Drug Release Profile

Release kinetics of HA-Dox-PCN was analyzed by a Shimadzu RFPC 5430 spectrophotometer. Nanoparticles were dispersed in phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4). After dispersion, the Dox fluorescence intensity was measured (excitation wavelength, 480 nm). To determine the induced drug release profile, HAdase (400 U/mL) was added to the nanoparticle solution at 4 h and the release profile was analyzed using fluorescence.

elements.content: A Newport IQE-200 solar simulator (Irvine, CA) was used as a light source. The power density for light was 40 mW/cm2. To measure the generated singlet oxygen (1O2), anthracenediyl bis­(methylene)­malonic acid (ABDA) and nanoparticles (100 and 20 μM) were prepared in distilled water. The absorbance of ABDA is attenuated after reaction with 1O2 from PCN-224. The degree of absorbance change before/after photoirradiation implies the absolute amount of generated 1O2. Absorbance was obtained for every 2 min under the irradiation.
elements.clean_text:
Singlet Oxygen Generation Analysis

A Newport IQE-200 solar simulator (Irvine, CA) was used as a light source. The power density for light was 40 mW/cm2. To measure the generated singlet oxygen (1O2), anthracenediyl bis(methylene)malonic acid (ABDA) and nanoparticles (100 and 20 μM) were prepared in distilled water. The absorbance of ABDA is attenuated after reaction with 1O2 from PCN-224. The degree of absorbance change before/after photoirradiation implies the absolute amount of generated 1O2. Absorbance was obtained for every 2 min under the irradiation.

elements.content: HA-FITC solution (1 mL, 2.5 nM) was placed in the vial, and PCN-224 (8.55 nM) and DI water (pH 7) were subsequently added to the HA-FITC solution. The volume of mixture solution was adjusted to 3 mL. The emission spectrum of the sample was recorded with excitation at 470 nm. After measurement, the normalized fluorescence intensities calibrated by respective controls at 520 nm were plotted against the concentration of PCN-224. The nonlinear least-squares curve-fitting analysis was conducted to estimate the complex stability.
elements.clean_text:
Binding Constant Analysis

HA-FITC solution (1 mL, 2.5 nM) was placed in the vial, and PCN-224 (8.55 nM) and DI water (pH 7) were subsequently added to the HA-FITC solution. The volume of mixture solution was adjusted to 3 mL. The emission spectrum of the sample was recorded with excitation at 470 nm. After measurement, the normalized fluorescence intensities calibrated by respective controls at 520 nm were plotted against the concentration of PCN-224. The nonlinear least-squares curve-fitting analysis was conducted to estimate the complex stability.

elements.content: The cells were cultured (using RPMI 1640 and Dulbecco’s modified eagle medium (DMEM) media, respectively) while supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 μg/mL streptomycin, and 100 U/mL penicillin under incubation at 37 °C and humidified with 5% CO2.
elements.clean_text:
Cell Culture

The cells were cultured (using RPMI 1640 and Dulbecco's modified eagle medium (DMEM) media, respectively) while supplemented with 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS), 100 μg/mL streptomycin, and 100 U/mL penicillin under incubation at 37 °C and humidified with 5% CO2.

elements.content: Cells (5 × 103 cells/well) were cultured in sterile 96-well Nunc (Thermo Scientific Inc.) plates for 24 h and treated with different concentrations of PCN, HA-Dox-PCN (1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 μg/mL) for 12 h in the dark, and then, media were replaced with fresh media and the cells were irradiated for 30 min at 1 sun light (100 mW/cm2) using a solar simulator. Cells were incubated for another 12 h before checking the cell cytotoxicity using the Alamar blue dye assay by following the manufacturer’s protocol (DAL 1025, Invitrogen).
elements.clean_text:
Cell Viability Analysis

Cells (5 × 103 cells/well) were cultured in sterile 96-well Nunc (Thermo Scientific Inc.) plates for 24 h and treated with different concentrations of PCN, HA-Dox-PCN (1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0, and 5.0 μg/mL) for 12 h in the dark, and then, media were replaced with fresh media and the cells were irradiated for 30 min at 1 sun light (100 mW/cm2) using a solar simulator. Cells were incubated for another 12 h before checking the cell cytotoxicity using the Alamar blue dye assay by following the manufacturer's protocol (DAL 1025, Invitrogen).

elements.content: To check the endocytosis-mediated uptake pathway of HA-Dox-PCN, MDA-MB231 cells were seeded in a four-well chambered coverglass (Lab Tek II, Thermo Scientific Inc.) and pretreated with different inhibitors including sucrose (clathrin-mediated uptake, 400 nM), methyl-β cytodextrin (caveolae-mediated uptake), and amilorin (macropinocytosis) in serum-free DMEM for 1 h and replaced with fresh media. Afterward, HA-Dox-PCN were added to the medium for another 1 h of incubation. Then, the cells were analyzed under a confocal microscope (Olympus FV 1000) connected to a CO2 incubator.
elements.clean_text:
Endocytic Pathway Analysis

To check the endocytosis-mediated uptake pathway of HA-Dox-PCN, MDA-MB231 cells were seeded in a four-well chambered coverglass (Lab Tek II, Thermo Scientific Inc.) and pretreated with different inhibitors including sucrose (clathrin-mediated uptake, 400 nM), methyl-β cytodextrin (caveolae-mediated uptake), and amilorin (macropinocytosis) in serum-free DMEM for 1 h and replaced with fresh media. Afterward, HA-Dox-PCN were added to the medium for another 1 h of incubation. Then, the cells were analyzed under a confocal microscope (Olympus FV 1000) connected to a CO2 incubator.

elements.content: The cellular uptakes of Dox-PCN and HA-Dox-PCN nanoparticles in HeK 293T, MDA-MB-231, and SCC-7 cells were investigated by live confocal microscope images (Olympus FV 1000 series). The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in a two-well chambered coverglass (Lab Tek II, Thermo Scientific). After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated with Dox-PCN or HA-Dox-PCN at a final concentration of Dox at 10 μg/mL at different time points and analyzed using a confocal microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Cellular Uptake Analysis

The cellular uptakes of Dox-PCN and HA-Dox-PCN nanoparticles in HeK 293T, MDA-MB-231, and SCC-7 cells were investigated by live confocal microscope images (Olympus FV 1000 series). The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in a two-well chambered coverglass (Lab Tek II, Thermo Scientific). After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated with Dox-PCN or HA-Dox-PCN at a final concentration of Dox at 10 μg/mL at different time points and analyzed using a confocal microscope.

elements.content: The cellular uptakes of HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN nanoparticles in HeK 293T, MDA-MB-231, and SCC-7 cells were investigated by a BD FACSVerse flow cytometer. The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in a six-well plate. After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated separately with HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN at a final concentration of Dox at 10 μg/mL for 3 h and the uptake was analyzed by the BD FACSVerse flow cytometer.
elements.clean_text:
Cellular Uptake Study of HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN by Flow Cytometry

The cellular uptakes of HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN nanoparticles in HeK 293T, MDA-MB-231, and SCC-7 cells were investigated by a BD FACSVerse flow cytometer. The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in a six-well plate. After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated separately with HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN at a final concentration of Dox at 10 μg/mL for 3 h and the uptake was analyzed by the BD FACSVerse flow cytometer.

elements.content: The cellular reactive oxygen (ROS) was measured by a BD FACSVerse flow cytometer in HeK 293T, MDA-MB-231, and SCC-7 cells after treatment with HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN. The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in a six-well plate. After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated separately with HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN at a final concentration of Dox at 10 μg/mL for 3 h followed by 30 min of light irradiation. Then, the cells were kept for another 2 h followed by treatment with freshly prepared 5 μM DHE for 30 min at 37 °C. Then, the cells were analyzed by a BD FACSVerse flow cytometer.
elements.clean_text:
Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) Generation Using Dihydroethidium (DHE) by Flow Cytometry

The cellular reactive oxygen (ROS) was measured by a BD FACSVerse flow cytometer in HeK 293T, MDA-MB-231, and SCC-7 cells after treatment with HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN. The cells were seeded at a density of 2 × 105 cells/well in a six-well plate. After 24 h of incubation, cells were treated separately with HA-Dox-PCN and Dox-PCN at a final concentration of Dox at 10 μg/mL for 3 h followed by 30 min of light irradiation. Then, the cells were kept for another 2 h followed by treatment with freshly prepared 5 μM DHE for 30 min at 37 °C. Then, the cells were analyzed by a BD FACSVerse flow cytometer.

elements.content: To investigate the interfacial structure between the HA coating and PCN-224 surface via molecular dynamics (MD) simulation and density functional theory (DFT) calculation, we modeled two kinds of model systems for PCN-224 MOF, i.e., slab and cluster models. Each model was taken from the crystal structure of PCN-224, which was obtained from experimental XRD analysis. For the charge balance around the Zr­(IV) atom, half of μ3-OH and μ-OH in each Zr6 node were substituted by μ3-O and μ-H2O, respectively, as suggested by Park et al.’s work. The slab model was modeled as a thin monolayer slab perpendicular to the (100) surface, which was composed of eight Zr6 nodes and eight TCPP ligands, with about 70 Å of vacuum region (Figure S7a). Dangling bonds and charge imbalance due to (100) surface cleavage were compensated by adding two hydroxyl groups to each Zr6 node, i.e., (Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(μ-OH)8(μ-H2O)6)8TCPP8. For the cluster model, we employed three fragmented cluster models to represent the structure around the Zr6 node in the bulk and surface regions as well as the TCPP ligand, respectively (Figure S7b–d). The TCPP ligand was so bulky that it was replaced by a carboxyphenyl functional group in the Zr6 cluster. Thus, the Zr6 cluster model in the bulk region was composed of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(μ-OH)6(μ-H2O)6(C6H5COO)6, whereas that in surface region was composed of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(μ-OH)8(μ-H2O)6(C6H5COO)4. These cluster models were employed for calculating partial charges of PCN-224 (Figure S8 and Table S1) and for calculating the formation mechanism of the coordination bond.
elements.clean_text:
Theoretical Methods

Molecular Modeling

To investigate the interfacial structure between the HA coating and PCN-224 surface via molecular dynamics (MD) simulation and density functional theory (DFT) calculation, we modeled two kinds of model systems for PCN-224 MOF, i.e., slab and cluster models. Each model was taken from the crystal structure of PCN-224, which was obtained from experimental XRD analysis. For the charge balance around the Zr(IV) atom, half of μ3-OH and μ-OH in each Zr6 node were substituted by μ3-O and μ-H2O, respectively, as suggested by Park et al.'s work. The slab model was modeled as a thin monolayer slab perpendicular to the (100) surface, which was composed of eight Zr6 nodes and eight TCPP ligands, with about 70 Å of vacuum region (Figure S7a). Dangling bonds and charge imbalance due to (100) surface cleavage were compensated by adding two hydroxyl groups to each Zr6 node, i.e., (Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(μ-OH)8(μ-H2O)6)8TCPP8. For the cluster model, we employed three fragmented cluster models to represent the structure around the Zr6 node in the bulk and surface regions as well as the TCPP ligand, respectively (Figure S7b-d). The TCPP ligand was so bulky that it was replaced by a carboxyphenyl functional group in the Zr6 cluster. Thus, the Zr6 cluster model in the bulk region was composed of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(μ-OH)6(μ-H2O)6(C6H5COO)6, whereas that in surface region was composed of Zr6(μ3-O)4(μ3-OH)4(μ-OH)8(μ-H2O)6(C6H5COO)4. These cluster models were employed for calculating partial charges of PCN-224 (Figure S8 and Table S1) and for calculating the formation mechanism of the coordination bond.

elements.content: To observe physical adsorption of HA polymers on nanoMOF, we employed the slab model and HA decamer, whose length was about 2–3 times longer than one side of the slab model. In the MD simulation, we modeled HA-MOF systems with three different numbers of HA decamers (i.e., 2, 4, and 6 HA decamers) near one side of the surface (Figure S9). In addition, to apply the hydrated condition in HA coating, hydrated models were also considered, where water molecules were packed in all void regions of each system. In the MD simulation, the PCN-224 slab was regarded as a rigid body, whereas HA and water molecules were free to move. To observe the relaxed configuration of HA, we carried out thermal annealing in the temperature range between 298 and 500 K for 3 ns. For the nonbonding interaction energy parameters of the slab model, universal force field and Mulliken charges obtained from DFT were employed. Atomic charges employed in MD simulation are summarized in Table S1. For HA polymers and water molecules, consistent valence force field was applied to describe bonding and nonbonding interaction parameters. The Lorentz–Berthelot combination rule was applied for the van der Waals parameters between the slab model and HA or water in the system.

Molecular Dynamics

To observe physical adsorption of HA polymers on nanoMOF, we employed the slab model and HA decamer, whose length was about 2-3 times longer than one side of the slab model. In the MD simulation, we modeled HA-MOF systems with three different numbers of HA decamers (i.e., 2, 4, and 6 HA decamers) near one side of the surface (Figure S9). In addition, to apply the hydrated condition in HA coating, hydrated models were also considered, where water molecules were packed in all void regions of each system. In the MD simulation, the PCN-224 slab was regarded as a rigid body, whereas HA and water molecules were free to move. To observe the relaxed configuration of HA, we carried out thermal annealing in the temperature range between 298 and 500 K for 3 ns. For the nonbonding interaction energy parameters of the slab model, universal force field and Mulliken charges obtained from DFT were employed. Atomic charges employed in MD simulation are summarized in Table S1. For HA polymers and water molecules, consistent valence force field was applied to describe bonding and nonbonding interaction parameters. The Lorentz-Berthelot combination rule was applied for the van der Waals parameters between the slab model and HA or water in the system.

elements.content: We investigated the formation mechanism of the coordination bond between HA and Zr6 metal node using the DMol3 program. The mechanism was predicted to be a dehydration condensation reaction by interaction between the carboxylic acid functional group of HA and the hydroxyl group coordinated to the metal node. For the DFT calculation, we employed the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional and DNP 4.4 basis set with the all-electron relativistic core treatment. The convergence criteria for energy, force, and displacement were set to 1 × 10–5 Ha, 0.002 Ha/Å, and 0.005 Å, respectively. To include the dispersion correction of the van der Waals effect, the Tkatchenko–Scheffler scheme was used. The electrostatic contribution in the hydrated condition was considered by applying the conductor-like screening model, with the dielectric constant of water (ε = 78.54). To calculate transition states in the formation mechanism of the coordination bond between Ha and Zr6 metal node, we employed complete single linear synchronous transit and quadratic synchronous transit methods and the convergence criteria of the root-mean-square force was set as 0.002 Ha/Å.
elements.clean_text:
Density Functional Theory (DFT)

We investigated the formation mechanism of the coordination bond between HA and Zr6 metal node using the DMol3 program. The mechanism was predicted to be a dehydration condensation reaction by interaction between the carboxylic acid functional group of HA and the hydroxyl group coordinated to the metal node. For the DFT calculation, we employed the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional and DNP 4.4 basis set with the all-electron relativistic core treatment. The convergence criteria for energy, force, and displacement were set to 1 × 10-5 Ha, 0.002 Ha/Å, and 0.005 Å, respectively. To include the dispersion correction of the van der Waals effect, the Tkatchenko-Scheffler scheme was used. The electrostatic contribution in the hydrated condition was considered by applying the conductor-like screening model, with the dielectric constant of water (ε = 78.54). To calculate transition states in the formation mechanism of the coordination bond between Ha and Zr6 metal node, we employed complete single linear synchronous transit and quadratic synchronous transit methods and the convergence criteria of the root-mean-square force was set as 0.002 Ha/Å.

elements.content: The crystal structure of PCN-224 has a she topology with Im3̅m space group that contains three-dimensional open channels with the size of 1.9 nm. As biocompatible Zr­(IV) has strong interaction with the carboxylate linker, Zr nodes provide the framework robustness and thus ensure that the drug is delivered to cancer cells stably. In addition, the porphyrinic linker in the MOF framework allows efficient PDT without aggregation in the aqueous solution. PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized using a synthetic method described in a previous report. Synthesized PCN-224 nanoparticles were observed to have a spherical morphology with the diameter of 100 nm by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) (a,b). Nanoparticles of this size have a higher cellular uptake ability than that of other sizes. The structure of synthesized nanoparticles was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The experimental PXRD pattern of the MOF nanoparticles matches well with the simulated pattern (c) and still maintains crystallinity after HA coating, implying that the MOF structure remains during the synthesis process. The nanoMOF has a large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 2296(8) m2/g by N2 adsorption studies at 77K (d, S1a). This high surface area allow drug loading in large quantities, demonstrating the potential of the PCN-224 nanoparticles as a drug delivery carrier. We investigated the loading capacity of the hydrophobic Dox in nonmodified PCN-224 through physical entrapment. The drug encapsulation mechanism is caused by noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions, allowing PCN-224 to interact more effectively with the drug molecule. As shown in Figure S2, PCN-224 showed high loading capacity ability (108%, weight ratio between Dox and nanoMOFs). The porosity of Dox-PCN was confirmed by N2 adsorption. The BET surface area of Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. Although the surface area and pore size of Dox-PCN decrease, the porosity of Dox-PCN still remains after drug loading (Figure S1c).

elements.content: Along with a major limitation in the MOF drug delivery system, the hydrophobicity of the particle surface and open pores of Dox-PCN can cause low colloidal stability and premature drug release. To overcome such drawbacks, the Dox-PCN has been modified by an HA biopolymer through the coordination interaction with the Zr cluster and the carboxylic acid of HA. The DLS experiment indicated an increase in the hydrodynamic radius of HA-Dox-PCN (∼250 ± 20 nm) compared to that of PCN-224 (∼164 ± 20 nm) (e). After HA coating, MOF still showed the spherical morphology (Figure S3). The structural differences among PCN-224, Dox-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN were confirmed by TGA. After modifying the Dox and HA with PCN-224, TGA data show different thermal decomposition processes, although a quantitative calculation of the component ratio is difficult because of the pyrolysis temperature overlap of TCPP, Dox, and HA (Figure S4). Furthermore, surface properties of PCN-224 and HA-Dox-PCN were determined by measuring the ζ-potential in aqueous solution. The ζ-potential experiment indicated a change of the surface charge from a positive potential for PCN-224 (+27 mV) to a negative potential for HA-Dox-PCN (−34 mV) (f). The size and surface charge change indicates that HA was coated successfully on the PCN-224 surface. The HA-Dox-PCN colloidal stability was studied by measuring the size change through varying the time in media. As shown in a, the particle size did not show any significant difference for 48 h, indicative of high colloidal stability. The nanoparticle colloidal stability is important for the safe and effective nanomedicine since low colloidal stability of nanoparticles can lead to capillary blockage in vivo and the nanoparticles are likely to be rapidly removed by the body’s reticuloendothelial system.

elements.content: There are two possible driving forces of HA coatings: (i) by electrostatic interactions since the highly negatively charged HA can interact with the highly positive surface potentials of PCN-224 and (ii) by the coordination bond of HA with the Zr cluster. To investigate the main driving force of HA coating, we observed the effect of salt concentration in the HA coating process. We hypothesized that if the main driving force was the electrostatic interaction, the coating of HA onto PCN-224 would be influenced by the ionic strength of the solution since an increase in the ionic strength weakened the electrostatic interactions. A modified amount of HA was confirmed at different sodium chloride concentrations by the carbazole assay, which is commonly used to measure the amount of HA.

We hypothesized that if the main driving force was the electrostatic interaction, the coating of HA onto PCN-224 would be influenced by the ionic strength of the solution since an increase in the ionic strength weakened the electrostatic interactions. elements.content: As shown in b and S6, the amount of HA was independent of the concentration of sodium chloride and sodium acetate. More interestingly, the HA coating was quite stable even at a high salt concentration (200 mM). These results imply that the coating of HA might have happened by the polyvalent coordination bonds, along with simple electrostatic interaction and single coordination bonds. To further investigate the binding between HA and PCN-224, fluorescence titration was performed. Different molecular weights of FITC-modified HA (high-molecular-weight HA (1500–2200 kDa) and low-molecular-weight HA (8–15 kDa)) were prepared to compare the binding constant. The fluorescence of FITC-modified HA (FITC-HA) was significantly quenched when PCN-224 nanoparticles were added, probably due to the energy transfer from FITC to the porphyrin framework (c and S5). The normalized fluorescence intensities of FITC-HA at 520 nm were plotted against the ratio of the nanoparticle to the polymer. The binding constants (K s) were obtained through the nonlinear least-squares curve-fitting analysis. K s of high-molecular-weight HA-FITC with PCN-224 is 2.9 × 1011 M–1. Meanwhile, that of low-molecular-weight HA-FITC with PCN-224 was significantly decreased to 3.19 × 107 M–1. These results suggest that a large number of carboxylate groups of HA affect the binding force. Therefore, polyvalent coordination bonds with Zr clusters on the surface of PCN-224 nanoparticles are very important for a robust and stable gatekeeper system.

elements.content: To further investigate HA coating on nanoMOF, we first observed the physical adsorption of HA on the surface of PCN-224 via molecular dynamics simulations (see the section). In the low HA coverage systems with two decamers in the coating layer in the dry and hydrated conditions, HAs became adsorbed along the pore edge of the PCN-224 due to the formation of hydrogen bonds (Figure S10). However, as the number of HA decamers increased to six to thicken the HA coating, an amorphous coating layer was formed, resulting in the blocking of the pore structure in nanoMOF. More specifically, at the outermost surface of nanoMOF with HAs in the dry condition, −OH in HA (e.g., carboxylic acid and hydroxyl group) stably interacted with the terminal hydroxyl group of the Zr6 nodes (Figure S11a) and the amine group of the TCPP linkers. Even in the hydrated condition, a similar molecular configuration was observed while the hydroxyl groups and the water molecules interacting with each other, as shown in d and S11b, contributing to stably locating the HA coating layer near the surface. We conjectured that the formation of a coordination bond between HA and nanoMOF would be driven by this strong hydrogen-bonding force.

More specifically, at the outermost surface of nanoMOF with HAs in the dry condition, -OH in HA (e.g., carboxylic acid and hydroxyl group) stably interacted with the terminal hydroxyl group of the Zr6 nodes (Figure S11a) and the amine group of the TCPP linkers. elements.content: To verify the formation of a coordination bond between HA and the Zr6 node, the thermodynamic parameters were calculated via density functional theory (DFT) calculations (e,f and S12). By considering molecular configurations observed at the hydrated condition in molecular dynamic simulations, the HA monomer and the water molecule were placed near the terminal −OH group of the Zr6 cluster. To make coordination bonds between HA and nanoMOF, we assumed that the reaction would occur at the structure interconnected by hydrogen-bonding interactions, i.e., water molecule, carboxyl acid in HA, and terminal −OH group of the Zr6 cluster. In the initial reaction, a hydrogen atom was transferred from carboxylic acid of HA to the terminal −OH group of the Zr6 node, which was stabilized by an adjacent water molecule. Subsequently, the remaining carboxylate was coordinated to an open Zr site, accompanying 4.16 kcal/mol of activation energy (E a) and −6.63 kcal/mol of heat of reaction (ΔE). From IM1 to FS, the as-made water molecule was readily detached from the Zr atom and concurrently the carboxylate was coordinated to the Zr atom with 9.43 kcal/mol of E a and −13.25 kcal/mol of ΔE. Considering this relatively low E a, if the HA polymer was closely located to the Zr6 metal node of PCN-224, the polymer was expected to construct a new coordination bond with PCN-224 even at room temperature.

elements.content: Due to high expression of HAdase in cancer cells, the gatekeeper HA can be degraded inside cancer cells to trigger the release of the drug molecules. We first monitored HA degradation by HAdase in aqueous solution by observing the change of the surface charge. As shown in f, the surface charge of HA-PCN was changed from −34 to +4 mV after incubation with HAdase. This indicates that the coated HA on PCN-224 was degraded by HAdase. The HAdase-triggered drug release was investigated by measuring the emission of released Dox from HA-Dox-PCN.

elements.content: As shown in a, when HAdase (400 U/mL) was added to the HA-Dox-PCN aqueous suspension after 3 h of incubation, the Dox fluorescence intensity was gradually increased, implying that HAdase induced the drug release by degrading the HA that was attached to the PCN-224 surface. Meanwhile, only HA-Dox-PCN indicated stable encapsulation of Dox without unwanted drug release. It suggests that HA efficiently blocked the PCN-224 pore entrance before degradation by HAdase.

elements.content: To facilitate the dual therapy, we chose the water-stable PCN-224 consisting of Zr and a porphyrinic organic ligand, which is used as a sensitizer for PDT. The (4-carboxyphenyl)­porphyrin photosensitizer that constitutes PCN-224 can use light to produce 1O2. 1O2 generation was investigated by measuring ABDA absorption decrease under photoirradiation. As shown in b and S16, ABDA absorbance decreased consistently by increasing the illumination time. Additional advantage of HA coating is selectively targeting cancer and controlled drug release by HAdase inside the cancer cells. The cancer-targeting ability was confirmed by monitoring cellular uptake experiments. The prepared HA-Dox-PCN was incubated with Hek 293T (human embryonic kidney 293 cells, CD44-negative cells), MDA-MB-231 (human mammary gland or breast cancer cells), and SCC-7 (murine squamous cell carcinoma, CD44-positive cells). After 2 h of incubation, the cellular uptake ability of HA-Dox-PCN was observed by confocal microscopy and flow cytrometry (FACs). MDA-MB231 and SCC-7 cell lines showed higher intensity of Dox compared to that of the Hek 293T cell line (c and S14). It is well known that CD44 is overexpressed on the surface of cancer cells. Meanwhile, Dox-PCN showed low cellular uptake ability in all cell lines (Figures S13 and S14). Thus, these results suggest that HA-Dox-PCN nanoparticles can selectively uptake CD44 receptor-expressing cancer cells. The cellular uptake pathway experiment was conducted to confirm the more accurate invasion mechanism of HA-Dox-PCN. Figure S15 shows that the cellular uptake of HA-Dox-PCN is associated with clathrin-mediated endocytosis. ROS generation in the cell was confirmed by the FACs. HA-Dox-PCN effectively generated the ROS in the MDA-MB231 and SCC-7 cell lines under light irradiation (Figure S17).

elements.content: The therapy effect of PCN, HA-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN was investigated by measuring the cellular viability. Hek 293T (CD44 negative), MDA-MB-231­(CD44 positive), and SCC-7 (CD44 positive) cell lines were incubated with PCN-224, HA-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN. Only PCN-224 showed toxicity to CD44-negative cells under light irradiation (d and S18). Meanwhile, HA-PCN showed toxicity under light irradiation in CD44-positive cells (Figure S19). In addition, HA-Dox-PCN showed increased toxicity in light irradiation (e and S20). These results suggest that HA facilitated the selective uptake of cancer cells and the combined chemo-photodynamic therapy increased the cancer therapy effect under light irradiation. Furthermore, MCF-7/ADR cells (multidrug-resistant (MDR) human breast cancer) were prepared to observe the HA-Dox-PCN therapy effect in the MDR cell. MCF-7/ADR cell showed low cell viability when incubated with HA-Dox-PCN under light irradiation (Figure S21).
elements.clean_text: The therapy effect of PCN, HA-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN was investigated by measuring the cellular viability. Hek 293T (CD44 negative), MDA-MB-231(CD44 positive), and SCC-7 (CD44 positive) cell lines were incubated with PCN-224, HA-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN. Only PCN-224 showed toxicity to CD44-negative cells under light irradiation (d and S18). Meanwhile, HA-PCN showed toxicity under light irradiation in CD44-positive cells (Figure S19). In addition, HA-Dox-PCN showed increased toxicity in light irradiation (e and S20). These results suggest that HA facilitated the selective uptake of cancer cells and the combined chemo-photodynamic therapy increased the cancer therapy effect under light irradiation. Furthermore, MCF-7/ADR cells (multidrug-resistant (MDR) human breast cancer) were prepared to observe the HA-Dox-PCN therapy effect in the MDR cell. MCF-7/ADR cell showed low cell viability when incubated with HA-Dox-PCN under light irradiation (Figure S21).

elements.content: In summary, we developed an enzyme-responsive polymer gatekeeper system on nanoMOF for the combined chemo and photodynamic therapy. NanoMOF, PCN-224, has very high loading capacity for hydrophobic Dox through physical adsorption due to the large surface area of nanoMOF. The polymer gatekeeper, HA, blocks the pore entrance to preserve drug molecules inside the pore and prevents premature release through polyvalent coordination bonds along with electrostatic interaction. HA-Dox-PCN system specifically target the cancer cells and drug release was triggered by responding HAdase enzyme stimulation. In vitro experiment for the combined chemo and photodynamic therapy showed higher therapeutic efficacy under light irradiation. Moreover, this system effectively treats the MCF-7/ADR drug-resistant cell compared to the Dox chemotherapy. Thus, our HA-Dox-PCN, controlled drug release system, expands the role of nanoMOF as a drug carrier.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we developed an enzyme-responsive polymer gatekeeper system on nanoMOF for the combined chemo and photodynamic therapy. NanoMOF, PCN-224, has very high loading capacity for hydrophobic Dox through physical adsorption due to the large surface area of nanoMOF. The polymer gatekeeper, HA, blocks the pore entrance to preserve drug molecules inside the pore and prevents premature release through polyvalent coordination bonds along with electrostatic interaction. HA-Dox-PCN system specifically target the cancer cells and drug release was triggered by responding HAdase enzyme stimulation. In vitro experiment for the combined chemo and photodynamic therapy showed higher therapeutic efficacy under light irradiation. Moreover, this system effectively treats the MCF-7/ADR drug-resistant cell compared to the Dox chemotherapy. Thus, our HA-Dox-PCN, controlled drug release system, expands the role of nanoMOF as a drug carrier.

cln_elements.content:
PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized in a solvothermal condition as reported. meso-tetra­(4-carboxyphenyl)­porphine (TCPP) (100 mg, 0.13 mmol), ZrOCl2·8H2O (300 mg, 0.93 mmol), benzoic acid (2.8 g, 23 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (100 mL) were combined in a 250 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was heated to 90 °C for 5 h with 300 rpm stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The product was collected by centrifugation with 15 000 rpm for 30 min and washed by fresh DMF and acetone. The synthesized PCN-224 sample was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

Characterization of Dox-PCN

The dried Dox-PCN sample was activated at 60 °C for 30 min and at 80 °C for 12 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The BET surface area for Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).

Synthesis of FITC-HA

Hyaluronic acid (20 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of DI water (pH 7). Then, 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)­carbodiimide (15 mg, 97 μmol) and NHS (11 mg, 96 μmol) were added in HA solution. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Then, amine-modified FITC (2.2 mg, 5 μmol) was added in the mixture solution. After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the mixture was purified by dialysis using a 2.5 K dialysis bag for 1 week. After dialysis, the solution was removed by the freeze drier.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of PCN-224 (100 nm)

PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized in a solvothermal condition as reported. meso-tetra(4-carboxyphenyl)porphine (TCPP) (100 mg, 0.13 mmol), ZrOCl2⋅8H2O (300 mg, 0.93 mmol), benzoic acid (2.8 g, 23 mmol), and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) (100 mL) were combined in a 250 mL round-bottom flask. The mixture was heated to 90 °C for 5 h with 300 rpm stirring and then cooled to room temperature. The product was collected by centrifugation with 15000 rpm for 30 min and washed by fresh DMF and acetone. The synthesized PCN-224 sample was characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD).

Characterization of Dox-PCN

The dried Dox-PCN sample was activated at 60 °C for 30 min and at 80 °C for 12 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The BET surface area for Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).

Synthesis of FITC-HA

Hyaluronic acid (20 mg) was dissolved in 10 mL of DI water (pH 7). Then, 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)carbodiimide (15 mg, 97 μmol) and NHS (11 mg, 96 μmol) were added in HA solution. The mixture was stirred at room temperature for 4 h. Then, amine-modified FITC (2.2 mg, 5 μmol) was added in the mixture solution. After stirring at room temperature for 24 h, the mixture was purified by dialysis using a 2.5 K dialysis bag for 1 week. After dialysis, the solution was removed by the freeze drier.

cln_elements.content:
Before gas adsorption measurement, 100 nm PCN-224 samples were thoroughly washed thrice with DMF and twice with acetone. After decanting acetone, samples were dried under vacuum for 3 h. Also, the dried powder was activated at 85 °C for 30 min and at 120 °C for 5 h on ASAP 2020 for N2 adsorption measurement. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area for PCN-224 is 2296(8) m2/g. The corresponding pore size distribution was analyzed by the nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT).

Results and Discussion

The crystal structure of PCN-224 has a she topology with Im3̅m space group that contains three-dimensional open channels with the size of 1.9 nm. As biocompatible Zr­(IV) has strong interaction with the carboxylate linker, Zr nodes provide the framework robustness and thus ensure that the drug is delivered to cancer cells stably. In addition, the porphyrinic linker in the MOF framework allows efficient PDT without aggregation in the aqueous solution. PCN-224 nanoparticles were synthesized using a synthetic method described in a previous report. Synthesized PCN-224 nanoparticles were observed to have a spherical morphology with the diameter of 100 nm by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and scanning electron microscope (SEM) (a,b). Nanoparticles of this size have a higher cellular uptake ability than that of other sizes. The structure of synthesized nanoparticles was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). The experimental PXRD pattern of the MOF nanoparticles matches well with the simulated pattern (c) and still maintains crystallinity after HA coating, implying that the MOF structure remains during the synthesis process. The nanoMOF has a large Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 2296(8) m2/g by N2 adsorption studies at 77K (d, S1a). This high surface area allow drug loading in large quantities, demonstrating the potential of the PCN-224 nanoparticles as a drug delivery carrier. We investigated the loading capacity of the hydrophobic Dox in nonmodified PCN-224 through physical entrapment. The drug encapsulation mechanism is caused by noncovalent interactions such as hydrogen bonding and van der Waals interactions, allowing PCN-224 to interact more effectively with the drug molecule. As shown in Figure S2, PCN-224 showed high loading capacity ability (108%, weight ratio between Dox and nanoMOFs). The porosity of Dox-PCN was confirmed by N2 adsorption. The BET surface area of Dox-PCN is 1353(5) m2/g. Although the surface area and pore size of Dox-PCN decrease, the porosity of Dox-PCN still remains after drug loading (Figure S1c).

Along with a major limitation in the MOF drug delivery system, the hydrophobicity of the particle surface and open pores of Dox-PCN can cause low colloidal stability and premature drug release. To overcome such drawbacks, the Dox-PCN has been modified by an HA biopolymer through the coordination interaction with the Zr cluster and the carboxylic acid of HA. The DLS experiment indicated an increase in the hydrodynamic radius of HA-Dox-PCN (∼250 ± 20 nm) compared to that of PCN-224 (∼164 ± 20 nm) (e). After HA coating, MOF still showed the spherical morphology (Figure S3). The structural differences among PCN-224, Dox-PCN, and HA-Dox-PCN were confirmed by TGA. After modifying the Dox and HA with PCN-224, TGA data show different thermal decomposition processes, although a quantitative calculation of the component ratio is difficult because of the pyrolysis temperature overlap of TCPP, Dox, and HA (Figure S4). Furthermore, surface properties of PCN-224 and HA-Dox-PCN were determined by measuring the ζ-potential in aqueous solution. The ζ-potential experiment indicated a change of the surface charge from a positive potential for PCN-224 (+27 mV) to a negative potential for HA-Dox-PCN (−34 mV) (f). The size and surface charge change indicates that HA was coated successfully on the PCN-224 surface. The HA-Dox-PCN colloidal stability was studied by measuring the size change through varying the time in media. As shown in a, the particle size did not show any significant difference for 48 h, indicative of high colloidal stability. The nanoparticle colloidal stability is important for the safe and effective nanomedicine since low colloidal stability of nanoparticles can lead to capillary blockage in vivo and the nanoparticles are likely to be rapidly removed by the body’s reticuloendothelial system.

As shown in b and S6, the amount of HA was independent of the concentration of sodium chloride and sodium acetate. More interestingly, the HA coating was quite stable even at a high salt concentration (200 mM). These results imply that the coating of HA might have happened by the polyvalent coordination bonds, along with simple electrostatic interaction and single coordination bonds. To further investigate the binding between HA and PCN-224, fluorescence titration was performed. Different molecular weights of FITC-modified HA (high-molecular-weight HA (1500–2200 kDa) and low-molecular-weight HA (8–15 kDa)) were prepared to compare the binding constant. The fluorescence of FITC-modified HA (FITC-HA) was significantly quenched when PCN-224 nanoparticles were added, probably due to the energy transfer from FITC to the porphyrin framework (c and S5). The normalized fluorescence intensities of FITC-HA at 520 nm were plotted against the ratio of the nanoparticle to the polymer. The binding constants (K s) were obtained through the nonlinear least-squares curve-fitting analysis. K s of high-molecular-weight HA-FITC with PCN-224 is 2.9 × 1011 M–1. Meanwhile, that of low-molecular-weight HA-FITC with PCN-224 was significantly decreased to 3.19 × 107 M–1. These results suggest that a large number of carboxylate groups of HA affect the binding force. Therefore, polyvalent coordination bonds with Zr clusters on the surface of PCN-224 nanoparticles are very important for a robust and stable gatekeeper system.

Due to high expression of HAdase in cancer cells, the gatekeeper HA can be degraded inside cancer cells to trigger the release of the drug molecules. We first monitored HA degradation by HAdase in aqueous solution by observing the change of the surface charge. As shown in f, the surface charge of HA-PCN was changed from −34 to +4 mV after incubation with HAdase. This indicates that the coated HA on PCN-224 was degraded by HAdase. The HAdase-triggered drug release was investigated by measuring the emission of released Dox from HA-Dox-PCN.
